ca.uqac.lif.labpal.plot.gnuplot

Class ClusteredHistogram

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.uqac.lif.labpal.plot.Plot
      • ca.uqac.lif.labpal.plot.gnuplot.GnuPlot
        • ca.uqac.lif.labpal.plot.gnuplot.ClusteredHistogram
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    TwoDimensionalPlot

    public class ClusteredHistogram
extends GnuPlot
implements TwoDimensionalPlot
    Two-dimensional bar diagram, also called a "clustered histogram".

    Example usage. Suppose you have a set of experiments, each with three parameters:

    • name is the name of a web browser (Firefox, IE, etc.)
    • market is the name of a market (video, audio, etc.)
    • share is the market share (in %) for this browser in this market
    We wish to create a bar diagram where each bar represents a market, its height corresponds to the share, with one group of bars for each browser. To is done by writing: 
     BarPlot plot = new BarPlot();
 ...
 plot.useForX("browser").useForY("share").groupBy("market");
    This will create a histogram that looks like this: 
     |                     # video
 |                     $ audio
 |                     @ text
 |    $
 |    $@         @
 |   #$@        $@
 |   #$@       #$@
 +----+---------+----->
   Firefox     IE
    Author:
    Sylvain Hall√©

    • Method Detail

      • rowStacked

        public ClusteredHistogram rowStacked()
        Sets whether the histogram is of type "row stacked". Using the example given above, the rowstacked setting will rather produce this plot: 
         |                     # video
 |                     $ audio
 |    @                @ text
 |    @         @
 |    $         @ 
 |    $         $ 
 |    #         # 
 +----+---------+----->
   Firefox     IE
        Returns:
        This plot

      • boxWidth

        public ClusteredHistogram boxWidth(float w)
        Sets the box width of the histogram. This is equivalent to the boxwidth setting of Gnuplot.
        Parameters:
        w - The width (generally a value between 0 and 1)
        Returns:
        This plot
